p.text: The Corporations Law Rules 2000 were notified in Gaz 144 of 24 December 1999 p 12,279 and commenced 1 March 2000. The title of the Rules was amended to Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 by the Corporations Law Amendment (No 3) Rules 2003, Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377. The Rules have been amended by:
These Rules may be cited as the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999.
[r 1.1 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
These Rules effectively replace the provisions of Pt 80A for matters commenced under the Corporations Law after 1 March 2000.
These Rules commence on 1 March 2000.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,010] r 1.3 Application of these Rules and other rules of the Court

leg:heading.title: Application of these Rules and other rules of the Court

p.text: Unless the Court otherwise orders:
these Rules apply to a proceeding in the Court under the Corporations Act , or the ASIC Act , that is commenced on or after the commencement of these Rules, and
Division 15A applies to a proceeding in the Court under the Cross-Border Insolvency Act .
[subr (1) subst Gaz 132 of 17 October 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 17 October 2008]
The other rules of the Court apply, to the extent that they are relevant and not inconsistent with these Rules:
to a proceeding in the Court under the Corporations Act , or the ASIC Act , that is commenced on or after the commencement of these Rules, and
to a proceeding in the Court under the Cross-Border Insolvency Act that is commenced on or after the commencement of Division 15A .
[subr (2) subst Gaz 132 of 17 October 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 17 October 2008]

Unless the Court otherwise orders, the rules applying to a proceeding in the Court under the Corporations Act , or the ASIC Act , as in force immediately before the commencement of these Rules, continue to apply to a proceeding under the Corporations Act , or the ASIC Act , that was commenced before the commencement of these Rules.
By virtue of the definition of this Act in section 9 of the Corporations Act, a reference to the Corporations Act includes a reference to the Corporations Regulations.
[subr (3) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608]
[r 1.3 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,015] r 1.4 Expressions used in the Corporations Act

leg:heading.title: Expressions used in the Corporations Act

p.text: Unless the contrary intention appears, an expression used in these Rules and in the Corporations Act has the same meaning in these Rules as it has in the Corporations Act .
Expressions used in these Rules (including the notes to these Rules) that are defined in the Corporations Act include:
(short for “Australian Business Number”) — see section 9

[r 1.4 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
In these Rules, unless the contrary intention appears:
means a person claiming interlocutory relief in a proceeding.
means the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 of the Commonwealth.
[def insrt Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
means the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth.
[def insrt Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
means the Corporations Regulations 2001 of the Commonwealth.
[def insrt Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
means the Cross-Border Insolvency Act 2008 of the Commonwealth including, unless the contrary intention appears, the Model Law.
[def insrt Gaz 132 of 17 October 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 17 October 2008]
means a person against whom relief (except interlocutory relief) is claimed under the Corporations Act , the ASIC Act or the Cross-Border Insolvency Act , whether in the originating process or not.
[def am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 132 of 17 October 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 17 October 2008]
means an interlocutory process in accordance with Form 3 .

means the Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law, the English text of which is set out in Schedule 1 to the Cross-Border Insolvency Act, with the modifications set out in Part 2 of that Act.
[def insrt Gaz 132 of 17 October 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 17 October 2008]
means an originating process in accordance with Form 2 .
means a person claiming relief (except interlocutory relief) under the Corporations Act , the ASIC Act or the Cross-Border Insolvency Act , whether in the originating process or not.
[def am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 132 of 17 October 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 17 October 2008]
means a person against whom interlocutory relief is claimed in a proceeding.
[def rep Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
[r 1.5 am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,025] r 1.6 References to Rules and Forms

p.text: In these Rules, unless the contrary intention appears:
a reference to a rule is a reference to a rule in these Rules; and
a reference to a form followed by a number is a reference to the form so numbered in Schedule 1 to these Rules.

It is sufficient compliance with these Rules in relation to a document that is required to be in accordance with a form in Schedule 1 if the document is substantially in accordance with the form required or has only such variations as the nature of the case requires.

Without limiting subrule (1) , the Court or the Court officer must not reject a document for filing only because a term used to describe a party in the document differs from the term used in these Rules.
Legislation cited in [15,030.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1322.

Section 1322 Corporations Act 2001 confers on the court a wide power to give legal effect to proceedings where there has been an omission or irregularity which would otherwise invalidate the proceedings: Omega Estates Pty Ltd v Ganke [1963] NSWR 1416; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 1218 . Meetings and resolutions are “proceedings”: Bell Resources Ltd v Turnbridge Pty Ltd (No 2) (1988) 13 ACLR 762; 6 ACLC 970; BC8800999 . No irregularity invalidates proceedings under the Corporations Act unless the court considers that (i) it cannot be remedied and (ii) may cause substantial injustice: JSBG Developments Pty Ltd v Kozlowski (2009) 74 ACSR 531; 239 FLR 288; [2009] NSWSC 1128; BC200909671 at [21]–[30] per Barrett J (the irregular commencement of proceedings by a director, without the intervention of a solicitor — separate question answered — no evidence adduced or submissions made in relation to “substantial injustice” issue).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,035] r 1.8 Court's power to give directions

p.text: The Court may give directions in relation to the practice and procedure to be followed in a proceeding if it is satisfied, in the circumstances of the proceeding, that:
the provisions of the Corporations Act , the ASIC Act , or the rules of this Court do not adequately provide for the practice and procedure to be followed in the proceeding; or
a difficulty arises, or doubt exists, in relation to the practice and procedure to be followed in the proceeding.
[r 1.8 am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,035.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 14, 61.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 2.1.

This rule complements the court’s general directions powers under CPA ss 14 and 61 , and UCPR r 2.1 . It permits, for example, dispensation with the requirements of particular rules, where the court is satisfied that they do not adequately provide for the particular circumstances: Re Tumut River Orchard Management Ltd (in liq) [2011] NSWSC 915; BC201106164 at [11]–[13] per Hammerschlag J (application by equitable assignee to fill liquidator’s vacancy — direction dispensing with Corporations Rules r 7.2 requirement for application by ASIC, a creditor or a contributory).
If, for any purpose, these Rules:
prohibit, permit or require an act or thing to be done within, by, or before the end of; or
otherwise prescribe, allow or provide for;
a period of time before or after a particular day, act or event, the period is to be calculated without counting that day, or the day of the act or event, as the case may be.

Without limiting subrule (1) , in calculating how many days a particular day, act or event is before or after another day, act or event, only the first day, or the day of the first act or event, is to be counted.

If the last day of any period prescribed or allowed by these Rules for an act or thing to be done falls on a day that is not a business day in the place where the act or thing is to be or may be done, the act or thing may be done on the first business day in the place after that day.
In calculating a period of time for the purposes of these Rules, the period beginning on 25 December in a year and ending at the end of 1 January in the next year is not to be counted.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,045] r 1.10 Extension and abridgment of time

p.text: Unless the Corporations Act , the ASIC Act , or these Rules otherwise provide, the rules of this Court that provide for the extension or abridgment of a period of time fixed for the doing of any act or thing in relation to a proceeding apply to a proceeding to which these Rules apply.
[r 1.10 am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
